I use a skil mag77 and treat it with the utmost respect, doing everything I can to prevent binding and kickback. In my years of using my saw almost daily to make my living I have only had two kickbacks, both of which I rightly predicted were about to happen.
Now I'm not a big guy, 5' 10" 150 lbs, I am fairly strong for my size I think having worked with my hands my whole life, my grandpa called it farmers strength lol.
My point is, both of my kickbacks I simply braced my arm for the impact and completely arrested the saw, both times the piece I was cutting exploded and splintered away from me and the saw remained motionless.

So that's some background, now on to my question:
What are the odds that these two events were just very minor kickbacks and is it possible for the forces to just be too much for any human to resist? We're my events not catastrophic because, based on my shear experience with the tool I was able to predict the event and brace for it? Certainly that is a factor. But being safety conscious, I'm looking for opinions about whether these were just very minor kickbacks compared to what is possible.
I understand that not everyone that uses a saw has the benefit of being as experienced as I am, or is as strong as I am because of the life and career I chose, so maybe they're more dangerous to others?
Asking because my second kickback was a few days ago and I figure this channel probably has some people that are smarter than me about such things.
Any opinions, stories, or advice would be greatly appreciated.

A couple things about kickback: 1. It's almost completely avoidable. The only times I've had a saw try and kick was when I had done something stupid in terms of supporting the wood I'm cutting or the placement of the saw. As he shows in this video it mainly happens when the wood falls in and pinches the blade. The vast majority of the time you can avoid this by properly supporting the work. But there are awkward situations where you need to cut things.. Dimensional lumber can often have internal stresses that make the wood move once cut. Or it can be cupped/bowed/twisted. (these only really come into play when you are making a rip cut)
2. Know when you are doing something dangerous and get a real good grip on the saw: If you can control the initial kick you can overpower the saw. But if you let it get loosey goosey on you it's trouble time. Keep that blade embedded in the wood till you can turn the saw off!
3. Plan for failure. Fail to safety.

The problem with this is the same problem that Steve Gass (designer of the SawStop) had when trying to license his invention to the table saw manufacturers. If the TS makers started shipping their saws with this new "safer" technology it would be a tacit admission that the products they sold without the new technology were "unsafe", and that would leave them open to massive litigation. Of course the opposite is also true, that if they continued to sell old technology while newer, safer technology was available, they would be opening themselves up to litigation over whether their products SHOULD have the new tech (see Osorio v. Ryobi).

Personally I think your idea is brilliant and, assuming you can make the additional cost reasonable, major saw manufacturers would be stupid to not adopt it, but I also wouldn't hold my breath. You might want to contact the SawStop company and sell the idea to them!

Any tool is dangerous if not used and maintained correctly. As a carpenter of over 30 yrs, kick back only occurred when my mind was not concentrating on the job at hand. (A) Your riving knife has been removed. To prevent binding, a piece of metal (called the riving knife) is secured behind the blade to prevent the wood binding the blade. On longer cuts, a wedge can be placed into the cut to hold the timber apart. (B) The spring loaded blade guard seems to have been disabled. As soon as the blade leaves the timber, the guard is designed to spring back, covering the blade. Check the spring action. Note, knocks and bangs can cause the guard to be bent and not work correctly. (C) NEVER start any tool with the blade in contact with the material. This is the reason for the majority of kick backs with all power tools. Move the blade away from the material, allow the tool to reach working speed before bringing it into contact with the material. (D) Learn how to use tools safely, and be aware of the material you are cutting. Circular saws should always be held firmly with two hands. Never stand behind the blade, your body should be at 90 degrees to the blade, moving along the workpiece as you cut. Ensure that your path beside you material is clear to walk - remove debris or cables that may trip you up. To keep the power cable for the tool you are using out of your way, my teacher taught us to drape it over the shoulder, - prevents cutting the cable or tripping over it. (E) Allow the tool to cut at it's own speed. Never force the blade to cut quicker than it is designed to. This will blunt the tool quicker, and may cause kick back. Harder materials or deeper cuts will require more time to cut.
All power tools are dangerous if not used correctly. Knowing how to use a tool correctly removes most of that danger (except for spindle moulders, even professionals can get caught out). A great concept for DIY builders, but I doubt it will get fitted to professional tools, as learning how to use the tool properly will negate the need for extra cost. Stay safe :)

I landed my first carpentry job,,, because the guy before me died. Circular saw kickback that rotated up into his abdomen. I walked on site unaware asking for a job just over an hour later. Three years later a coworker was seriously injured when a saw kicked back across his thigh.


I went out a few days later and purchased a Black and Decker Super Sawcat, 8.25", with a dynamic brake. It was 10 times the cost of other saws at the time. I used, exclusively Black and Decker Super Sawcats for the next 40 years. My last one died last year. I now use a Makita with no brake, Basically,, I hate it. It was designed by a college educated engineer who had never,,, never used it on a job site. A beautiful, powerful tool, that requires three hands for safe operation. I, of course, do not have three hands so there are distinct compromises to safe operation on a daily basis.

The dynamic blade stop is the first and most important safety feature. The second is never,,, I emphasize that word,, never ,, be behind the saw during cutting,, always at right angles to the cut line. Always,, the cord must be on the clear side of your body. Many injuries have occurred because the cord guided the saw around a person and then across some body part.


And your basic suppositions of speed and power of the kickback are absolutely correct. No human can sense and respond to a full kickback faster than the saw can injure you.. For nearly all saws,, keep saw and cord out to your right, (there are a few left hand saws) , never cut something that is supported or fastened on both ends (the waste piece must be allowed to fall away), always grip your saw as though your life depends up[on it. Never ever- EVER -support the work on the cutoff side of the saw. That’s sawing 101!!!!
Always secure the work under the motor (heavy) side of the blade and allow the cutoff to drop away from the blade. For sheets and awkward pieces support both sides nearly equally under the work to avoid blade pinch. I use stringers across under the work for sheetgoods and barely score them as I make my cut. Chipping is reduced as well.

It’s important to always set the blade to the proper depth. Just deep enough to clear the underside a bit. That way the cutting action is nearly horizontal and teeth clear the chips vertically. Then the cutoff drops away and down. If a circular blade is set too deep it will make a nearly vertical full thinkness cut forcing the material to twist and buck the blade.

As a computer engineer I am not exactly sure if machine learning is neccessary, in many cases as a human you can really easily find certain logics and thresholds by looking at test data. However in more complex cases where you cannot really derive a logic by yourself machine learning can really be an effective way of doing it. But in general it usually it is better to come up with your own logic, since machine learning has its own set of quirks. Especially for safety applications it is preferably since you can never really know whiche logic was learned by the machine. Btw a good training of e.g. given a neural network will be really costly too.

E.g. if you use a machine learning algorithm for this and you only record kickbacks at 0 degree cutting it could not at all work at 45 degree cutting. Or if you cutting on a non even surface it could either behave radically or not at all. Of course those things can happen also with a selfmade logic however you at least can deduct where the error in your logic was and how to improve that. You mostly cannot deduct the origin of the problem with a trained algorithm, you might be able to improve it by adding the problematic scenario to your training data, but still you cannot know if this will fix this problem for all kinds of angles, materials and blades.

Taking this all together it seems to me that a machine learning algorithm will bring more problems with it than it solves for this particular (relatively simple) case. I am also pretty sure, that detecting a harsh acceleration backwards plus some other minor factors like the saws body rotation could be pretty good in recognizing a real kickback and even differentiate it from man made shaking. But even if the logic could not differentiate kickbacks and shaking, would it be a problem if someone is prevented from running around with a running saw and shaking it? You even might get simular or slightly better results via ML but it would be a bigger hassle and you just cannot be sure about that, so the classic approach would definitely win for me. I mean in the end you obviously have to test this, but I am pretty sure on this one.

Why not use a simple switch that in engaged when the metal frame is pressed against the wood + the only way to run the motor is having that switch & the trigger engaged? When the thing lifts off, the switch disengages and a breaking routine can be executed by the motor controller. The switch itself can be mechanical or an optical distance (or contact) sensor, both are inexpensive and the second one can have a small range defined as "in contact" to compensate for movement during cutting with minor lifts etc. If you combine two of them at both ends of the shield you can even glide with the saw over the edge of the wood and as long as one of them senses contact the motor can run. I see two benefits for this approach - lower development cost and the second is very cheap hardware to implement in the saw which is something manufactures will like.

There is a fundamental question brought up here about education of users vs fool-proofing. A common fear, and one I share, is that while smart people like Chad use extreme ingenuity and intelligence to make products safer, the everyday user is in effect being coddled into negligence. This is not to say they can't coexist.

Simpler safety devices are (generally) met with less resistance. Is it the intuitive nature of things like blade guards that allow them to feel warranted, or is it just a feeling of 'when is it going to end; when is it going to be safe enough!?' Perhaps it really comes down to cost-benefit (or said differently, complication vs effectiveness). Can the same level of effective protection be achieved more simply?

Take the table saw flesh sensing tech as an example. Despite a table-saw being quite similar in principle to a circular saw, the user interface is vastly different. Because of some operations performed on a table-saw, simple passive safety guards are often unusable or moot. This is a case where the high tech sensing tech seems to really have a place.

Perhaps this tech would have a place on consumer grade saws. Or conversely on large, high powered saws in situation where passive measures might become unusable/cumbersome (float cutting scribe lines on non-planer wood).

By far the most effective safety device is education. Even with computer controlled kickback devices and flesh sensing tech, proper tool use should be top of every entity involved in the industry of tool use.

@SmarterEveryDay As cool a solution as this is, I feel I have to point out you may have reinvented the wheel a little here. Look up "Dual Blade Buzz Saw" or Dual Blade Circular Saw, or "Counter Rotating Saw". They use a pair of circular blades that spin in opposite directions, So that when they grip the material being cut, they don't kick. This solution already exists to the problem, and I feel it's a safer solution that the one here. As a computer scientist / programmer, I understand ANN programming, and one of the draw backs of intuitive AIs from Artificial Neural Networks is that with large ones, it becomes impossible to verify that it will always be 100% accurate. There is always a chance the network will not behave as you want it to. And we can't foresee what may cause a network to return a false positive, or in this case much worse, a false negative.
Neural networks which train themselves hold their intuitive-like-behavior as their greatest upside as well as their greatest downside. Neural networks, such as the one used by google's Deep Mind are known for being able to surprise the researchers who created them, because they don't follow a simple set of instructions designed entirely by the researcher/programmer, and they find their own solutions. This becomes a great upside when you want to solve complex problems that require intuition, but it also becomes a downside when it comes to safety, because you cannot pinpoint the cause of a failure when one happens, nor can you manually go in and edit it to fix a part that causes a false positive/negative. You can only hope that the genetic algorithm (or whatever learning algorithm is used) will find a solution and do so without opening up any new false positives/negatives.

Kickback is a direct result of an inexperienced user not understanding or ignoring the feedback that the saw is giving the user through changes in motor speed, sound, cutting resistance, vibrations and force applied and yet continuing to push the saw through the cut until the saw bites the wood and bucks back.

The experienced saw user can process all those feedback points, on the fly and instantaneously, as he is operating the saw and anticipate and modify his cutting approach to avoid kickback. This is achieved only through good training and consistent proper use which in turn produces muscle memory that guides the user through the cut safely and efficiently.

Lifetime circular saw user here. I love the idea, but as a potential consumer, I'm skeptical. For anyone who would care, here are my concerns. I will assume that the technology can be implemented with next to zero loss in appearance or functionality- exempli gratia, these saws won't be heavier, or have some goofy digital device sticking off the side of them. 

First, understand that the actual threat of "kickback" in the hands of a capable user is minimal. Two prepared hands will stop a circular saw from moving. The bulk of danger with one of these things comes from the potential for the guard to stick/fail. A user will naturally develop comfort with a power saw over time. As such, the first time the guard sticks, there is a high probability of a close call. This is why a brake is so important. Any power saw is loud and intimidating, which is why there is so much fear surrounding its use. The noisy intimidation might act as a red herring that makes us overcorrect for safety, because we might believe that there is danger where there is none. My argument here is simply that false positives have consequences.  

Understand that it is a contrivance of the market to promote any gimmick that touts "safety," because there is a natural effort to secure positive PR and the appearance of social responsibility. SawStop is the classic case. Their product is extremely overrated, but their positive image has lots of sway on the lay person who would prefer to remain on the side of caution. But the bias of the misinformed has a funny way of making its way into policy- which, I'm afraid, may eventually lead to manufacturing regulations, which become additional expense to the consumer. Such impositions also become unquestioned design assumptions which then stifle the diversity of engineering techniques available to tool manufacturers. The result is a market filled with cookie-cut, disposable tools that are nowhere near optimized for function. From a business perspective, marketability optimization is the preferred product line.     

Another incursion upon consumer choice and personal liberty comes in the form of patent protection. This is of course a complicated problem, because ideas do have origins, and those originators do have some claim to benefit from their own ideas. But as our market runs presently, some types of protection will freeze the market's ability to adapt to the new idea and to then provide healthy competition until the patents expire, as SawStop has done. If it were really about saving fingers, I think SawStop would have taken a slightly different approach. But this paragraph is telling us something we all already knew.

As a potential consumer, it's my concern that even a well-intentioned technology has a funny way of being turned into a useless sales pitch- especially if that new technology has an opportunity cost of forcing some other aspect of the product to become 'shaved off,' to try to compensate for the price of including that new technology. For example, cords on saws now are cheaper and less flexible than they used to be. This saved manufacturers money, and made the saws cheaper, but with a stiff cord, there is now a small loss to worker productivity and safety that's nearly impossible to measure empirically. What will this new technology displace in order that the price will remain reasonable? A cheaper trigger, perhaps? How about a guard spring that has a thinner gauge? These are complicated problems, and I don't think the answer is as unconditionally simple as safe=good. As such, I post this critique in the hopeful spirit that this technology will be well-implemented and non-invasive. I don't really expect anybody to read this, but that really is my hope. The idea seems to come from a good place. 

Just for noobs:
Here are a few lesser-considered risks associated with a power saw: 1) setting the blade unnecessarily deep. This gives the sawblade more exposed area, and further, more leverage to cause damage. 2) using a dull blade. A sharp blade maintains its speed through the cut, so it has less chance of binding. 3) failure to consider the internal stresses of the medium. Wood has an intricate network of internal tensions and compressions. Learning to keep the two halves of the board away from one another while keeping one part stationary and the other free will all but eliminate the possibility of bind/"kickback."

And finally, and most importantly: there is no substitute for good procedure. No corrective mechanism for "safety" can replace a capable brain. Learn how to hold your saw.

I'm a 48 year-old contractor who has watched tool after tool being taken over by the safety  police at OSHA.  Almost without exception, small power tool safety devices make equipment more dangerous for professionals while making them only marginally more safer for homeowners.  Many guards for instance require the operator to contort their body in ways that leading to less control over the tool  when it gets bound. Similarly, some tools require you to hit multiple buttons to turn them on causing the user to have an excessive grip on the device  such that the device  becomes less safe during  use .  This works out well for the manufacturer's because contractors take the safety devices off of the machines the minute they put them in the service, thus indemnify  the manufacturer. But the removal of such devices is becoming more and more difficult to do. For instance, devices that prevent you from using a pneumatic nailer to shoot your buddy from across the room also inevitably cause you to dent finnish material. And the newest line of such products one can't actually remove the safety plunger. As a result to use the tool properly you actually have to hold the plunger with one finger while you shoot the gun with the other. Occasionally, a nail goes through the wood makes a hundred eighty degree turn and lodges into the finger. This is extremely painful, but the alternative to this happening once or twice every couple of years is putting dents in finished Hardwood on every last job. This is an unacceptable outcome. So my request would be that if you do program such a thing in the device that you put an off switch, similar that used to turn off the airbags on the passenger side of a modern car, so that we don't have to break open the electronics to fix a bad implementation. If you do this I would definitely consider buying that tool. Otherwise, the fewer gadgets in a tool, the better the tool will perform.

I really like your science, but you induce a proper kickback by sawing cross-grain. It will send the board flying in the opposite direction of the saw and the saw will fly backward. It seems to be possible to happen when the width of the board is more than the length of the board. Actually it happens with anything that is more wide than long. The grain does not really matter. The reason is that the forward momentum of the saw makes the sides of the board pivot towards the blade and then they grip the blade, that makes the saw grip even harder in the wood and that will increase the radial momentum of the sides of the board, which grips even more onto the blade. Now you have a board flying out of the saw and the blade suddenly stop.

I love you videos BUT you are over complicating the circular saw with your "improvements".
First, your guard is up, big no no, guards are designed to cover the blade. The moment the saw separates from the wood surface the guard will be covering the gap.
You get kickback when 1. The blade runs into a knot and the operator doesn't reduce the travel force, preventing the blade from adjusting to the thickness difference. 2. The operator doesn't cut in straight line, binding the blade and 3. (Your scenario), the material has a natural warp/bend and it will close the gap created by the blade causing a jump at the rear. The operator can prevent the jump by maintaining control of the tool and slowing down the travel speed.

How can this problem be solved?
1.proper training
2. A rear depth-adjustable spacer/guide that is aligned with the blade that would fill the gap and prevent the wood from binding the blade. Just like the guards on table saw.

Again, LOVE you videos but don't expect any tool manufactures calling.

I don't know guys, the science is cool, but I'm not sure this is the application for it. In the testing, 2 things stand out to me: The blade guard is pinned back, and an un-muscled chain is 'holding' the saw, allowing it to pendulum back and away when the blade gets pinched. Sure people do foolishly pin back their blade guards, but those same foolish people would figure out a way to disable this feature (if indeed they shelled out the extra price to purchase it in the first place). Someone who would defeat one safety measure would surely defeat (or not purchase) another. And a human arm (or two) holding a saw has enough weight and muscle memory behind it to control the saw to some extent just from inertia. A kickback-inducing blade pinch might let the saw climb up out of the cut, perhaps all the way clear of the workpiece, but more likely would just stall or stop the saw. Unless you're half asleep and holding it with an exhausted spaghetti arm, or sawing while bracing the board over your thigh or something equally foolish on a Darwinian scale, your arm's stronger and heavier on the saw than this pendulum chain, and will (even unconsciously) control the force of the kickback before the saw gets near gonads or any other vital parts of the anatomy. A circular saw really is one of the safer power tools.

Now a parade of walking wounded will come out of the 'woodwork' (no pun intended) to list all their circular-saw-kickback stories and injuries (either real ones, or invented ones for the purpose of this discussion), but I still have yet to see a responsible woodworker using the saw correctly (or even less than correctly) being unable to control a circular saw kickback. It's a whole other kind of kickback than the table saw, where a 5,000 rpm motor is launching a projectile at you, or pulling your hand that was guiding the piece into the spinning blade when it walks up on a tooth, before you can react. Here, you're holding the much lighter saw itself, no bits of wood being flung at you. And you (or even your arm) has a lot more inertia through it's own mass and muscle memory than the circular saw kicking back has. And I'm not denying there have been circular saw kickback injuries, but what I am saying is that you gotta be doing so many obvious things wrong to get one, you probably should just save yourself the time and saw right across your fingers or thigh bone and be done with it. Sorry, I just don't see it.

Carpenter here:
1) Always use your circular saw from the side. That way if it does kick, it can only ruin your work and not your body as it will kick off to your right(with most saws)
2) Pay attention to what your saw is telling you. If it's slowing down, and you can tell it's getting pinched(or if you can see it) STICK A WEDGE IN THAT GAP. You have a saw in hand, you can make shims in seconds if you don't have any.
3) If you stop in the middle of a cut, back up an inch or so before resuming. This is what I have noticed is the most common cause of kickback among newbies. They keep pressure on where the teeth are sitting before even starting the saw up. Don't do that.

So, I'm not in the industry for safety related software, but as far as I know, using machine learning for safety critical application is not considered appropriate.
The issue with neural networks is that you can't tell what it has picked up as indicators. Maybe it is counting the amount of peaks, maybe the maximum acceleration (In reality it's a big mix of many things, since it isn't "picking" anything, just adjusting weights until it fits all cases). There have been cases already, where slight, seemingly benign chances to variables that shouldn't change the behavior of the software, suddenly changed the result drastically, simply because this variable has been the same in all cases.
Another issue in your case would be that generating enough data to train it for realistic kickback events (with humans holding the saw, different kinds of wood, different saw blades, different weight, etc.) is dangerous and would be a lot of work.
What would be better is to maybe try to detect the binding of the blade directly (by monitoring motor current for example), maybe combine it with an accelerometer and create a traditional, testable algorithm. Maybe this would create a few false alarms is special situations, but I'd rather have ten false alarms, than one kickback not being detected.

As someone who sells chainsaws at my job - this is because circular saws are built wrong. They should be built so you can draw them towards you. The issue is your rotating cutting surface is being slowed by the material in the WORST area of the blade BY DESIGN. In chainsaws you don't cut with the bottom half of the tip of the saw (or any of the tip if you can help it, but not always. Same in cutoff wheels - if you think of the circular blade as a clock face, you want to be cutting with about 6 to 11 o'clock part of the blade and NOT the front (especially not the front lower quadrant, ie 3 to 6 o'clock) because that causes the blade to kick up and back towards the user if the blade gets pinched or slows down suddenly due to harder material.


This problem would be much easier to solve by reversing the direction of cut while keeping the rotation direction the same. Make circular saws that you draw towards yourself and then put a dead man switch (ie if the saw kicks, then it will kick AWAY from you and if you lose your grip, the saw blade brake engages and stops the saw). Much better solution because BY DESIGN if kickback happens, it kicks the saw AWAY from the user (even if the safety brake/dead man switch combo fails the system is intrinsically safer than current saws).


In chainsaws you can't really swap the way you cut, so chainsaw makers came up with low kickback chains and bump guards to automatically stop the saw if the kickback is enough to cause the saw to jolt.


Secondly, if you make circular saws so that you draw cut with them instead of pushing them forward you're taking advantage of human instinct - when something goes wrong our reaction is to stiffen our arms to keep the saw away from us. This works complementary with the direction of kickback to keep the saw away from the operator if kickback happens. In current circular saws you don't want to push the saw away because if it catches on the wood again, it will just kick towards you again. You want to either hold it down, turn it off, or pull it up from the wood and keep hold of it - both of which are not our natural reaction in the moment.

If the saw becomes dislodged it's designed to slam shut and protect things from the spinning blade. Also, if the saw is coming towards your gonads, you're holding it wrong to begin with. Never stand behind the saw. You should be off to the blade side of the saw so that if it does buck, you're not right behind it. With proper handling procedures, you don't need to worry about human reaction time, because you don't need to react. As long as you're holding the saw properly, you should be able to let go of the saw entirely without risk of injury.
